ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: To be honest, I don't really feel like I gained much from this course. Some units were interesting, like learning about why certain earth phenomena occur, but the class format made it so that you really had to do most of the content learning on your own.
I learned a few things about planets and stars.
I learned foundational knowledge about astrophysics, planets, and stars in our Solar System and outside.
A great knowledge of planets, stars, and problem solving.

I learned about some basic concepts in astrophysics with regards to parallax, flux, luminosity, and orbital properties. We also covered what we know about stars, planets, and exoplanets, as well as how we know these things.

A lot actually. I learned so much about planets and stars and orbits and the physics of space. I also didn't just learn about these things, I learned how we know what we know about them. It's a really cool class
Learned basics of astronomy: planet formation, star formation, basics about solar system

I learned about the basics of our solar system, how it formed, basics about asteroids, /comet eye, and how astronomers learn about them.

Also a side topic - basic physics
QR
Developed knowledge of planet & star formation and characteristics, as well as general improved understanding of the universe as a whole.
I learned about planets and stars
I learned a lot about Planets Stars and the history of astronomy.
I learned a lot about astronomy and the universe, as well as an introductory level of astrophysics
General knowledge about planets, galaxies, star formation and demise. Analytical and scientific skills to better understand space.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I strongly disliked the class format. We had to watch 1-3 hours of lecture per week, and we had 2.5 hours of in class "group work" time. I felt that the lectures were often confusing, and it was hard not being able to ask questions (and it was also less engaging). The in-class time felt pretty useless -- we would have 30 second discussions about questions about topics that had been barely touched on in the lecture videos, and the TFs would end up having to explain most of it to us. We would do problems at whiteboards, but then we wouldn't have those problems in our notes, and when problems like those appeared on Problem Sets or exams and people were confused about them, Professor Faison would just say "we did one like that on the whiteboard." Overall, class felt like a waste of time, and I think the class would be much improved if in-class time was reserved for lectures, especially if the lecture included maybe a couple opportunities for group discussion or questions. The main strength of this class, in my opinion, is the TFs. All of our TFs were super helpful and very patient in explaining the concepts -- in class, in section, and over email. I wouldn't have made it through the class without them!

I do like the online lectures. it gives us a chance to pick when we will learn the material which can help us pick the best times we are most engaged. The parts of class involving going to a board to work on problems is clunky and usually not very helpful. It would be better if we all went through the problems together with people we want to be with and then had the classwork posted to canvas after for us to study for tests and homework.
The lectures honestly weren't as helpful as the textbook chapters, which seems backwards...

I think that professor Faison is very clear and good at articulating his ideas. However, I am strongly against the flipped classroom. I feel like learning online is much harder and I would prefer if we had in class lectures and a discussion section if you wanted to continue with the flipped classroom.
This course was good at using algebra to understand the vastness of space.

I think the format of the course is its weakness. You have one to three lectures to watch at home before class, and during class time, you have a giant class discussion. I truly don't think this helps with student learning or engagement. Most students won't watch the lecture before class and will have no idea what's happening during class. I don't think I learned much from the discussions, BUT I learned SO MUCH from watching the lectures. 


Also, getting to use telescopes after class and looking at the sun was really cool
It could be improved by not having all lectures online the night before. Feel like I would learn more with in person lessons.
Less hybrid style
The lectures did not overlap with the problem sets nor did they overlap with the problems we did in class.

strengths is professor very passionate, learned broad scope. weakness is class discussion felt kinda forced at times, not much incentive for people to participate, discussion groups people just giving bs answers
It was very useful going over course material twice a week. We had two classes and about two videos to watch a week - it made it very easy studying for midterms if we kept up with everything
It was slow

Classes and assignments was repetitive, which made it difficult to stay engaged as the semester progressed. I didn't feel like I learned much from the actual classes that I hadn't already been told in the online lecture beforehand. It was nice that those lectures were available to watch at any time though.
I liked the discussions during class it was nice to talk to classmates. Psets didnt always match class material
The course is great and the lectures are engaging. The problem sets could be a little shorter.
I liked the interactive class but the online lectures were not as beneficial to me as in person lectures are

Strength: Professor and TAs are incredibly caring and helpful in helping students digest the material. Weakness: The flipped class structure made the class somewhat time consuming at times, as students were expected to watch recorded lectures beforehand.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would say it depends. I took it to fulfill Science and QR requirements, and it's really nice that this course fulfills both of those requirements. The workload is manageable, and the PSETs aren't terrible (if you go to section), but the class itself is not well organized to maximize efficiency or learning. This class fulfilled a requirement and nothing more, but it probably is easier than other STEM classes.

It is a really interesting class if you actually like astronomy. You get to learn the fundamentals of the universe. I would for recommend for non-majors looking for a relatively easy class, but not a gut.
No.

I would recommend this course to another student if you truly have an interest in astronomy. I know some people who went into this class thinking it was just going to be easy, but it was harder than expected, so only take it if you have a genuine interest in the subject.
Yes.

I definitely would recommend the course to anyone who is genuinely interested in astronomy. Without some interest in astronomy, the weekly problem sets, prerecorded lectures, and in-class discussions can become tedious, but for those who enjoy learning about planets and stars, the workload will be well worth it! The course content is very interesting and covers a good range of various topics in astronomy.

Be ready to do lots of work for this class. It is low intellectual challenge, but the workload is really high. You have lectures to watch at home, you have to go to class for a discussion, AND there is a problem set every week.

If you can commit to that, this class is really awesome. At Christmas dinner, someone asked about Pluto not being a planet, and I went into a 30 minute discussion of the solar system. It was AWESOME. You will learn a lot of fun facts about the solar system :)
Yes, I really enjoyed it and it taught me a lot.
Yes, content is easy but there are 11 problem sets
Yes, I liked this course and thought it was paced well to learn about astronomy on a basic level.
yeah, good sc credit. not boring not too hard.
Yes - it was a good science credit that kids can do well in if they like physics.
Yes
THIS IS NOT A GUT CLASS

I would recommend this course to a non-science major looking for a relatively simple science credit accessible to non-science people. I wouldn't recommend it to somebody who is looking for a super interesting or inspiring course.
Yes fun class
Yes, absolutely. I think it provides a great backbone to understanding planets and stars.
Yes I enjoyed the material and thought it was a very fair and interesting class.
I would recommend this class to another student who is curious about space, planets, and stars.
